awd_titl_txt: Engagement in Engineering Pathways: An Initiative to Retain Non-Traditional Community College Students Using Peer-Led Instruction and Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
Student engagement in STEM coursework continues to be a challenge in undergraduate education and continues to be a barrier in the retention of all students, especially those that are underrepresented and/or non-traditional. To succeed in diversifying and increasing the STEM workforce, as well as improving the quality of STEM graduates entering the workforce, student engagement must improve. Valencia College is a highly diverse two-year, non-residential, open access public institution that serves the Orlando, Florida area. The goal of this project at Valencia College is to use peer-facilitated instruction in core engineering coursework known to have high attrition rates, with the goal of retaining non-traditional students in engineering. Adopting evidenced-based teaching and learning practices proven successful at four-year institutions, the intent of this project is to measure the impact on engineering students' engagement at two-year colleges with the aim of diversifying and broadening the participation in engineering. This project has potential to increase understanding of these methods in STEM courses at two-year colleges, as well as improve the teaching quality and student engagement at Valencia College. Further, the new knowledge generated during this project around the use of peer-facilitated instruction at two-year colleges has potential to improve the success and participation of non-traditional students in engineering and STEM disciplines across a broad range of institutions.

More specifically, the project will design and implement peer-facilitated recitation activities linked to fundamental engineering courses, such as engineering analysis, statics, and dynamics. At Valencia College, these courses have the highest failure rate among female and underrepresented minority students. Through the design and implementation of peer­led, problem-based, and contextualized real-world applications in these fundamental engineering courses, the goal of the project is to increase student engagement and persistence. As a cross-sectional study design, engagement will be measured using scales such as students' mathematics efficacy, engineering efficacy, academic self-concept, and sense of belonging. By adopting a teaching and learning model that has been effective at large research-intensive universities, the proposed project offers an innovative and adaptable approach to supporting and retaining diverse students at a community college in introductory engineering courses. Results from student metrics will inform faculty professional development efforts to increase faculty support and maximize student learning. The project will affect institution practices informed by data as well as reach a national audience in the STEM community to further ignite educational practice and educational research.

por.por_cntn:
Goal #1 for this project was to increase commitment to engineering pathways.

The first outcome under this goal was as follows: 70% of students participating recitation sessions will declare or maintain their status in a declared engineering pathway.

The second outcome under this goal was as follows: 60% of nontraditional (e.g. URM, and/or female) students participating in recitation sessions will declare or maintain their status in a declared engineering pathway.

The researchers were not able to obtain institutional transfer date on all participants in the experimental group, however, the following data was collected on the students with information reported to the National Student Clearing House. 88% (208 of the 264) of the students in the experimental group who enrolled and successfully passed the Statics course remained in an engineering pathway at the institution and/or declared an engineering major upon transfer to a four-year institution and 10% (23 out of 264) left engineering but remained in a STEM-pathway. There was total 380 students in Statics experimental group, but may be not 380 individuals as some students repeat the course.

84% (71 of 85) of the students that took Dynamics stayed in engineering and 12% (10 of 85) left engineering but remained in a STEM-pathway. There was total 100 students in Dynamics experimental group, but may not 100 individuals as some repeat the course.

100% (18 of 18) of the students that took Electrical Networks remained in engineering. There was total 24 students in the EGS 2004 experimental group.

Survey results for all students can be found in the image titled "Survey reponse for Goal #1".                            

Post-survey results for all female students years 1-3:

As a result of this class, do you feel more committed to getting an engineering degree and achieving career goals?

More than before ? 51.56% (33 out of 64)

Same as before ? 46.75% (28 out of 64)

Worse than before ? 4.68% (3 out of 64)

 

Goal #2 for this project was to increase persistence of URM, specifically Hispanic female students, in engineering courses.

The first outcome under this goal was as follows: 85% of Hispanic female students partiipating in recitation sessions will successfully complete (grade of C or better) engineering courses on first attempt, and persist to the next academic semester.

Overall (all 4 classes) passing rate for Hispanic female is 61.7% (42 out of 68), retention 77.04% (53 out of 68)   EGN 2312 – pass 58.7% retention 70.8% EGN 2322 – pass 63.2% retention 73.7%, EGS 2004 & EGS 2373  – pass & retention both 100%.

The second outcome under this goal was as follows: 75% of URM students participating in recitation sessions will successfuly copmlete (grade of C or better) engineering courses on first attempt and persist to the next academic semester.

If we consider only Female students then Overall (all 4 classes) passing rate for only female is 58.8% (100 out of 170), retention 76.47% (130 out of 170)   EGN 2312 – pass 56.88% retention 76.14% EGN 2322 – pass 58.33% retention 75%, EGS 2004– pass & retention both 100%, EGS 2373 – pass 66.66% retention 100%.

 

Goal #3 for this project was to increase faculty support.

The first outcome under this goal was as follows: 90% of faculty involved with E-path activities perceive a greater understanding of content material by students involved in recitation activities.

During the project, 100% of the faculty involved with E-path responded that they perceived a greater understanding of content material by students involved in recitation activities.

The second outcome under this goal was as follows: 95% of faculty involved with E-path activities observe increased opportunities to adequately identify at-risk students.

During the project, 100% of the faculty involved with E-path responded that they observed increased opportunities to identify at-risk students and work with specific students to resolve deficiencies.

The third outcome under this goal was as follows: 90% of faculty involved in E-path activities experienced increased involvement of students during the class after attending recitation hours.

During hte project, 100% of faculty involved with E-path experienced increased involvement of students during the class after attending recitation hours.

Please note there were only four faculty members involved with E-path.


Last Modified: 02/01/2022
Modified by: Lisa Macon

  • Table showing responses to survey question focused on commitment to engineering pathways.

    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Lisa Macon
    Survey response for Goal #1
